segments.text: Thanks for meeting me for dinner, Patricia. I know you're busy with the Riverside project prep.
Of course! I wanted to discuss the bid before the board meeting next week. Walk me through your thinking.
So we came in at 12.8 million, but we've identified value engineering options that bring it down to exactly 12 million.
The board set 12 million as the cap. What are we giving up to hit that number?
Primarily facade materials. We spec'd aluminum panels originally. The VE option uses fiber cement which looks nearly identical but saves 600k.
And the performance? I don't want to compromise on building longevity.
Fiber cement has a 50-year warranty. It's proven technology. The only difference is aluminum would've given you that premium look.
I can live with that. What's the timeline looking like?
Eighteen months from groundbreaking to certificate of occupancy. That's assuming we start by April.
April works. We need tenants moving in by fall of next year. Can you guarantee that timeline?
I can guarantee we'll do everything in our power. But you know construction - weather, supply chain issues, inspections. We build buffer time in.
I appreciate the honesty. Too many contractors promise the moon and then blame delays on acts of God.
Not my style. I'd rather under-promise and over-deliver. We've got a track record of finishing on time or early.
That's why we want to work with you. Okay, I'll recommend your bid to the board. Expect a decision by Friday.
Thank you Patricia. We're ready to hit the ground running as soon as we get the green light.
I have no doubt. Now, let's order. I'm starving and I hear the salmon here is excellent.

environment.background_sounds: restaurant ambiance, clinking dishes, background conversations, soft music
